stimulusHtml: A spring is attached to a fixed vertical wall and extends over a horizontal surface, as shown in the figure labeled “No Box.” In an experimental trial, a box is attached to and pushed against the spring, which has a spring constant k0, compressing the spring an amount D0 from its uncompressed length. The box is then released from rest and oscillates about its equilibrium position, with a maximum speed of v1. In a second trial, a spring with spring constant 2k0 and the same uncompressed length is used. The same box is attached to and pushed against the new spring, compressing it an amount D02 from its uncompressed length. The box is released from rest and oscillates about its equilibrium position, with a maximum speed of v2. There is negligible friction between the block and the surface. Are speeds v1 and v2 equal? What reasoning can be used to support the claim?
choicesHtml: No. In the second trial, the elastic energy initially stored in the spring is less than in the first trial.
No. In the second trial, the acceleration of the box at a given displacement is greater in magnitude than in the first trial.
Yes. In the second trial, the maximum force exerted by the spring on the box is the same as in the first trial.
Yes. In the second trial, the spring exerts twice the amount of force over half the distance as in the first trial when moving the box from its maximum displacement to the equilibrium position.
